newsitem.title: USA: Farm group seeks Clinton meet on vetoed tax break.
newsitem.headline: Farm group seeks Clinton meet on vetoed tax break.

text.p: Farm cooperative leaders on Thursday asked to meet with President Clinton to discuss how to revive a food processor tax break he vetoed earlier this week.
Clinton used his line-item veto authority for the first time Monday to strike down three provisions of the balanced budget accord he signed last week.
Clinton expressed support for the goal of the food processor tax break, which was intended to make it easier for farm cooperatives to buy processing facilities.

But he said details of the provision--which the administration estimated would cost $98 million over five years--were poorly designed. He promised to work with congressional supporters to recast the measure.

"On behalf of the nearly 4,000 farmer cooperatives across the U.S. and their nearly two million farmer members, we want to express our disappointment," David Graves, National Council of Farmer's Cooperatives president, said in a letter to Clinton.
"We believe this should be given an immediate high priority within the administration," Graves said.
The vetoed provision would have allowed food processors to defer capital gains taxes on the sale of assets to qualified farm cooperatives.
A similiar tax break exists under current law for employee stock ownership plans and worker cooperatives, the farm co-op council said.
